title: Instant observations: Sixers suffer ANOTHER third quarter collapse in loss to Lakers
description: The Sixers turned in another third-quarter meltdown to waste a good Joel Embiid performance, falling 119-115 to the Los Angeles Lakers in infuriating fashion. Here‚Äôs what I saw. Third quarter...
fullText:
The Sixers turned in another third-quarter meltdown to waste a good Joel Embiid performance, falling 119-115 to the Los Angeles Lakers in infuriating fashion.

Joel Embiid had just an okay game against the Clippers in Philadelphia‚Äôs barnstorming win on Monday, sitting out the second half of a back-to-back against Golden State the next night. It felt a little bit like he owed these guys something, if for no other reason than having the freshest pair of legs. And boy, did he deliver on that, sparking the Sixers early while playing a do-it-all hub on offense for a team that struggled to make shots for most of the night.

With the Lakers down Jaxson Hayes thanks to his mascot-related suspension ‚Äî yes, he really is that big of a clown ‚Äî DeAndre Ayton was the only guy close to like-sized that L.A. could throw at him. But it didn‚Äôt especially matter, outside of a few offensive rebounds Ayton pulled down at his expense. Ayton‚Äôs on-again, off-again effort is a bad matchup for an opponent who will take any bit of space and rise into a midrange jumper, and Embiid was able to get the shot going within the first five minutes of the game. When that happens, opponents are in jail trying to guard him, as it opens up opportunities to punish reach-ins and drive by jumpy defenders.

Outside of Ayton, the Lakers mixed up coverages and the defender primarily tasked with guarding Embiid. From Jarred Vanderbilt to Maxi Kleber and others across the spectrum, the main theme was a big size advantage for Embiid. On some nights, that might mean deep post catches and a free-throw parade, but with Embiid often operating from the middle of a zone, it meant a lot of jumpers his man could never get close enough to contest. One little jab step, one little body language cue, and the Lakers were falling all over themselves to stay with him, with Embiid rising into lightly-contested shots for the entire first half. 20 easy points at halftime, thank you very much.

Embiid had some sloppiness with the handle early, but he was killing the Lakers as a playmaker for others, too, punctuating his first half with an outstanding play: Embiid faked a handoff attempt to Tyrese Maxey, drove downhill into the space the Lakers left vacated, and as the defense collapsed on him in the paint, he released the ball to Dominick Barlow for an easy bucket, sending the Sixers into halftime on a high note.

Everything was rolling along until, you guessed it, the third quarter hit. I cannot believe we are this far into the season and still treating the quarter after halftime as an unsolvable Sphinx riddle for the Sixers to solve. Change the opponent, the venue, the players on the floor, nothing really matters. They will find a way to stink it up all the same.

There was a decided lack of seriousness from the Sixers after they surged to a double-digit lead early in the third, allowing the Lakers to get back into the game with seven turnovers in a single quarter. They were mostly in cruise control until about the halfway point of the third, and then the wheels came off. Nurse resisted turning to his bench as the Sixers held onto a small but mildly comfortable lead, and it all came crashing down in the end-of-quarter stretch, with Maxey battling foul trouble and Embiid resting on the bench.

Enter Quentin Grimes, a mystifying player to watch. His first half was filled with genuinely awesome moments, with Grimes best understanding what needs to be done when Austin Reaves is on the floor. Drawing him in isolation repeatedly, Grimes went right by him to the rim on several different occasions, making Reaves work as he tore up the Sixers on the other end. He also put down his second highlight dunk of the week with a hellacious throwdown over Jake LaRavia, who I presume had a family.

TELL THEM DON‚ÄôT JUMP, Q!!! üí•ü§Øpic.twitter.com/K78SL0bJGp

‚Äî PHLY Sixers (@PHLY_Sixers) February 6, 2026

The second half was what we will charitably refer to as an adventure. When Grimes checked into the game for his end-of-third minutes, the game almost immediately flipped in the wrong direction. He had a brutal turnover, a bad foul, and a miscommunication with VJ Edgecombe in quick succession, and the Lakers were surging. His first good play of that stretch, a steal near halfcourt, was nearly botched before order was restored, only for Kelly Oubre to launch a tightly-contested three with close to 20 seconds left on the shot clock. Not the time or the place, particularly when you‚Äôre 2/7 at the time, Mr. Oubre.

This was the first stretch of basketball over the last week where I felt they desperately needed Paul George. In those backup lineups where they try to buy rest for Embiid and Maxey, it tends to be George who emerges as a cooler head, attacking in isolation or offering spacing for VJ Edgecombe to attack in. With George in street clothes, we were back to early-season Sixers hoops, with the Edgecombe/Grimes/Watford/Oubre combo dying for some spacing, plus decision-making, and savvy.

Down two points with 27 seconds left, the Sixers apparently decided they would trap late and concede a basket instead of either defending the play straight up or fouling to play the back-and-forth game. On the ensuing possession with 12 seconds left, Maxey took a ridiculous foul-baiting three and lost them the opportunity for even a chance to tie or win the game.

One of the dumbest sequences in Sixers history, straight up.

VJ Edgecombe is what I would affectionately refer to as an all-action player, someone who rarely rests on his laurels who helps you win games no matter what the moment requires. Those guys can occasionally cross the line and go careening into the opponent, trying too hard to impact the game while it boomerangs back on them. But he is a rare breed of rookie, constantly playing with 100 percent effort while minimizing his wild moments on both ends of the floor.

In fact, Edgecombe often cleans up craziness from other players. Joel Embiid had the rare opportunity to throw him a lob on the break, tossing the ensuing pass so high that two VJ Edgecombes stacked on top of one another in a trenchcoat probably wouldn‚Äôt have reached the ball. But after making the attempt to meet it at the summit, Edgecombe collected himself quickly and saved it from going out of bounds, ultimately earning the Sixers an extra possession that ended with an Embiid midrange make. These plays are a constant in the Edgecombe experience.

The Lakers tried to dare the Sixers into beating them with the three-ball with a fair amount of zone, and Edgecombe was the only guy making outside shots to potentially get them out of it. He is slowly starting to figure out the happy medium on the break, darting through traffic for layups and dunks or slowing down to find an open shooter if those easy opportunities aren‚Äôt there. Edgecombe was one of their few solid options defending Austin Reaves, who gave L.A. a big lift off the bench, ripping him on a first-half possession before the Sixers got out and scored on the break.

At least, that was the case for the first half, because Edgecombe ran into a wall and struggled mightily in winning time for Philadelphia. He was a little too much gas without brakes, throwing up some wild attempts inside the arc with no whistles to save him. And even after he made a gigantic steal and hit a three and drew them within three, he and Grimes combined for one of the worst fouls of the season, fouling down three with 35 seconds left when a normal defensive possession would have sufficed.

But I was much more disappointed in Tyrese Maxey, who had an impactful passing game but a dire attacking performance, letting the Lakers dissuade him from getting past the initial defensive coverage while jacking missed three after missed three on stepback jumpers. Between true zone coverage and some extra bodies in the paint sagging off of questionable shooters, Maxey relied far too much on his jumper on a night where he had nothing going from deep.

Could the Sixers have been more purposeful with their offense to get him rolling? I think so, yes. First play of the game, they ran him off of an Iverson cut to get him a look closer to the basket, and rarely turned to off-ball action to get him looks the rest of the night.

If not for the lack of incoming players at the trade deadline, we‚Äôd have a real opportunity to celebrate Dominick Barlow, who is one of the great organizational success stories of the last two years. Signed to a standard deal on Thursday evening, Barlow rose quickly from an end-of-bench afterthought to an essential piece of this Sixers team.

It has been a big road trip for Barlow, who brought his standard brand of energy and athleticism to the arena against L.A. One of the high notes of a solid Sixers first half was an end-to-end sequence from Barlow, who came from the weakside to block Rui Hachimura on a deep catch before streaking to the other end, finishing with style for two points after outrunning the entire Lakers team in transition.

His night was defined by work in and around the dunker spot, with Barlow catching drop-off after drop-off from every available passer.

‚Äî In games where an opponent gets a whistle that seems ultra skewed against one team, my dad likes to shout to no one in particular, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like playing the Globetrotters!‚Äù It certainly felt like the Harlem Lakers were on the floor on Thursday night.

(All that said, the officials did not win this game for the Lakers. The Sixers happily gave this game away themselves. But Jenna Schroeder is the worst ref in the league and I don‚Äôt even think it‚Äôs close.)

‚Äî That was perhaps the worst Oubre game of his Sixers tenure and a version of him I thought he largely left behind in Charlotte. Embarrassing shot selection, miserable off-ball defense, every negative trait in his profile on full display all at once.

title: Heights senior joins elite company, ties scoring record
description: Wichita Heights senior Jalihn Timmons has etched his name in history, tying the school's single-game record that's gone untouched for nearly 28 years.
fullText:
WICHITA, Kan. (KSNW) ‚Äî Wichita Heights senior Jalihn Timmons has etched his name in history, tying the school‚Äôs single-game record that‚Äôs gone untouched for nearly 28 years.

Timmons had a standout performance in Heights‚Äô January matchup against Andover Central, scoring 43 points. Thirty-six of his 43 points came in the second-half of the game.

‚ÄúI told him, ‚ÄòYou‚Äôre getting close to the record of 43 points,'‚Äù Head Coach Gary Thomason said. ‚ÄúHe kind of looked at me like that little smirk, like, ‚ÄòReally, you‚Äôre not messing with me, are you?'‚Äù

‚ÄúHe told me, like beginning of the fourth quarter, that I was close to it, so I just thought I would go for it,‚Äù Timmons said.

Thomason says Timmons has always been a fearless scorer.

‚ÄúHe always wants the ball in his hands. Not so much to maybe score all the time, but we know he‚Äôs going make a good decision at the end of the day,‚Äù said the coach. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really, it‚Äôs really fun to coach someone like that who loves the game and just as important, he respects the game too.‚Äù

Timmons now holds a place in history alongside CJ Martin, who first set the record in 1998. It was previously held by City League legends Darnell Valentine and Aubrey Sherrod.

‚ÄúAll the hard players that came through the program, it just shows that I really put a lot of work in to be where I‚Äôm at,‚Äù Timmons said.

National Baseball Congress honors three new Hall of Fame inductees

Even with such an achievement, Timmons remains humble, giving credit to the guys around him.

His teammates don‚Äôt just feel like family, they‚Äôre actually related.

Timmons‚Äô younger brother Jordan Timmons and his first cousin Jorelle Hadley are right there with him on the court.

‚ÄúWe played in a backyard growing up, so yeah, we played a lot with each other growing up throughout the years,‚Äù Timmons said.

Together, the trio is always holding each other accountable. There‚Äôs a strong support system around Jalihn, as he navigates his final season.

‚ÄúOne thousand points is on the horizon for him, and he can take these guys into the postseason,‚Äù Thomason said.

Despite the historic achievement, Timmons continues to strive for more.

‚ÄúState championship,‚Äù Timmons said. ‚ÄúI feel like that‚Äôs something that I really have come close to in the past years, but I just haven‚Äôt been able to grasp it yet, and I‚Äôm hoping this year me and my team are able to get it done.‚Äù

Timmons is committed to the Hutchinson Blue Dragons to continue his basketball career.

title: Wilson's 2026 Dynapwr Forged irons add AI-tech to the iconic family
description: Wilson is releasing the newest addition to the legendary Dynapwr family with the 2026 Dynapwr Forged irons, rounding out a revilized lineup.
fullText:
Wilson is rounding out its 2026 releases with a great answer for improving players demanding better from their irons.

Wilson‚Äôs new Dynapwr Forged irons enter a crowded player‚Äôs distance spot in the market, but with a cavity back design and an AI-generated ‚ÄúVariable Face Technology,‚Äù they‚Äôre making a push toward the top of the category.

‚ÄúWe wanted to build on the success of the previous award-winning model, while taking strides to elevate the performance to the next level,‚Äù Ben Hanser, CAD engineer at Wilson Golf, said in a statement. ‚ÄúThe new iron is a statement of Wilson‚Äôs dedication to innovation and tradition. By combining forged precision with AI-driven design, we‚Äôve created an iron that delivers distance, control and feel in perfect harmony.‚Äù

Keep reading below for more on the Dynapwr Forged irons, including my take on the release.

While the previous generation Dynapwr Forged irons were super successful, the 2026 models improve on them by adding a new optimized face thickness with the help of AI. This eliminated the need for the power holes of the previous model.

The variable face thickness helps boost face flex, in turn increasing ball speeds.

Dynapwr Forged also has a new KR-CUP face design, which overlaps the face around the sole, enhancing face flex further, particularly on low strikes.

To help further improve feel in the forged 8620 carbon steel chassis, the cavities in the 3- to 9-iron are filled with urethane to enhance feel.

What is it: A player‚Äôs distance cavity back iron with a new AI-designed variable face thickness and urethane-filled cavity.

Who it‚Äôs for: Players who are advancing their ball striking ability and want something with a more premium feel without sacrificing forgiveness and speed, or moving to something as compact as a hollow-body.

Many people are going to ask if they should choose between the Dynapwr Forged or the Staff Model XB iron. But truthfully, the new Dynapwr Forged perfectly fills a gap between the XB and the standard Dynapwr iron.

The Dynapwr Forged is clearly in that player‚Äôs distance category with entries like the P790, JPX 925 Forged, Ti Fusion and many others for players looking for speed and forgiveness.

The Dynapwr Forged is going to fall on the larger and faster end of that spectrum, while the XB falls 

What‚Äôs the difference? I believe it depends on your trend. This Dynapwr Forged is great for a player who is improving and needs to build confidence, but also wants to start getting into the more premium feel. In other words, they are a player who is improving, rather than a player looking to recapture lost performance.

You can still benift from lots of modern technology, like the new varaible face thickness and urethane-filled cavity, but you can also hone in your precision with a more players shape than the Dynapwr irons.

Dynapwr Forged gives Wilson a very complete iron lineup with no one left out. Another step toward the restoration of one of golf‚Äôs (and sport‚Äôs) great brands.

Wilson‚Äôs new Dynapwr Forged irons are available for pre-order starting¬†Feb. 5¬†and will arrive at retail locations on¬†Feb. 19.

The full set will cost $1,199.99 for 5-GW with steel shafts or $1,299.99 for graphite. A 3- and 4-iron are also available through custom.

Want to find the best driver for your game in 2026?¬†Find a club-fitting location near you at True Spec Golf.

The post Wilson‚Äôs 2026 Dynapwr Forged irons add AI-tech to the iconic family appeared first on Golf.

title: High school boys wrestling: Juab continues dynasty with 10th straight state championship
description: High school boys wrestling: Juab cements dynasty with 10th championship
fullText:
It takes more than practice, sweat and grit to build a wrestling dynasty.

The Juab boys wrestling squad capped off its 10th consecutive state championship Thursday night at the Sevier Valley Center in Richfield.

‚ÄúIt really takes a community to be able to do this and give those kids something to perform for,‚Äù coach Joel Holman said. ‚ÄúI think the state wrestling tournament is the greatest sporting event hosted by the (Utah) High School Activities Association. The highs are the highest, and the lows are the lowest.‚Äù

Juab racked up 277.5 team points en route to the title, with Canyon View finishing runner-up with 232 points and Morgan in third with 165.

Outside of Juab‚Äôs triumph, one of the top stories of the night belonged to Union‚Äôs Tucker Roybal, who wrapped up his career with a remarkable fourth individual state title. He won his championship match by technical to finish the year with a 47-1 record.

For Juab, of the seven wrestlers that advanced to the finals, two earned individual state titles.

Kaden Martineau (150) delivered Juab‚Äôs first individual title of the tournament with a win by fall over Union‚Äôs Rowdy Roybal and Ladd Holman (190) picked up the team‚Äôs other individual title, pinning Emery‚Äôs Hazen Meccariello in just 48 seconds.

‚ÄúI came in feeling pretty confident,‚Äù Martineau said. ‚ÄúI knew I just had to come in and do my stuff.‚Äù

Martineau said being part of the championship team is an incredible experience.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs awesome to be part of this. Everyone here is so electric,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWrestling is just part of my life. Without it, I don‚Äôt know where I‚Äôd be.‚Äù

Added Ladd Holman, the coach‚Äôs son: ‚ÄúIt was fun for me, but it‚Äôs even more fun to be part of the team. It‚Äôs special to be here. Wrestling helped me reach some goals, but also deal with some setbacks.‚Äù

A junior, this marks his third consecutive state title, and he said the coaching staff, including his dad, are some of his best friends.

The finals began with Carbon‚Äôs Jantz Greenhalgh earning a third-round pin over Juab‚Äôs Jack Holman in the 106-pound division. Canyon View‚Äôs Jaxten Bowler edged Juab‚Äôs Trevor Cowan with a 5‚Äì4 decision at 113, while Union‚Äôs Grady Roybal won a 17‚Äì10 decision over Juab‚Äôs Jet Abbott.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs always going to be disappointment, but hopefully they learn not only to do hard things, but to do them with class and integrity,‚Äù Joel Holman said. ‚ÄúYou represent yourself, your program and your community.‚Äù

At 138, Carbon‚Äôs Riker Ohearon defeated Juab‚Äôs Drake Johnson by decision.

‚ÄúWhat stood out for me is that most everyone on the backside took third place,‚Äù Holman said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm proud of the guys who took their loss, shook it off and came back to score points for the team.‚Äù

Holman also expressed appreciation for the support the team receives from the Juab community, including donations, countless volunteer hours and a sea of crimson shirts filling the cheering section.

‚ÄúPeople know when we‚Äôre doing well,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs important because if you feel like no one cares, it‚Äôs easy to give up on yourself.

‚ÄúWhen you know the community is behind you, watching and wanting you to succeed, you don‚Äôt want to let them down.‚Äù

Beyond the wins on the mat, Holman said he hopes his athletes understand they represent more than just a high school wrestling team.

‚ÄúWrestling teaches the lessons of sports better than any other sport because it‚Äôs harder than any other sport,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúJuab is a wrestling town, and now we have kids in the program who have never known Juab not to be a wrestling town.

title: Michael Carrick: Thomas Frank shares his verdict on United‚Äôs revival
description: Manchester United are preparing to face Tottenham Hotspur at Old Trafford on Saturday as Michael Carrick looks to make it four wins out of four.It has been a dream start for the caretaker head coach, ...
fullText:
Manchester United are preparing to face Tottenham Hotspur at Old Trafford on Saturday as Michael Carrick looks to make it four wins out of four.

It has been a dream start for the caretaker head coach, with the Red Devils seeing off Manchester City, Arsenal, and Fulham.

The manner of the wins was also impressive, with the 20-time English league champions playing Pep Guardiola‚Äôs side off the park before securing late wins against both London teams.

Ahead of Saturday‚Äôs crunch tie, Spurs boss Thomas Frank was asked to give his verdict about United under Michael Carrick.

The under-fire Dane went on to explain the two major differences he has noticed during the pre-match press conference.

He also added that United possess great individual quality to change games in an instant, highlighting Bruno Fernandes‚Äò impact as the attacking midfielder.

‚ÄúI think he has had a great start,‚Äù Frank was quoted as saying as per Sky Sports News. ‚ÄúIt seems like there was injected a little bit of energy into the team.

‚ÄúI think it looks like some of the players are in a good place. We know the threats that I also think they posed before from Bryan Mbeumo, Amad, Cunha and Bruno Fernandes, he‚Äôs getting this team ticking.

‚ÄúHe has done that the last, I don‚Äôt know, four or five years. It has been incredible. It is a threat, it is a challenge, but we are looking forward to it.‚Äù

Frank is spot on. The energy put in by the players, both offensively and defensively, has been a joy to behold and is a marked improvement from Ruben Amorim‚Äôs time at the club.

Something plenty of United stars have alluded to in recent interviews.

Not to mention, the legendary midfielder has also revitalised quite a few players who seemed down and out under the former head coach.

Kobbie Mainoo is a perfect example of that, while Carrick‚Äôs man-management also saw Patrick Dorgu shine in a more attacking role before his untimely injury.

Hopefully, the three-time Champions League winners can continue their mid-season revival and exact revenge on the North London side for what had transpired in the Europa League final in the last term.

Feature image Justin Setterfield via Getty Images

The Peoples Person has been one of the world‚Äôs leading Man United news sites for over a decade. bsky.social

title: Al Michaels Claims Steelers Had ‚ÄòGreatest Play In Super Bowl History‚Äô
description: There have been 59 Super Bowls in NFL history, and thus too many great plays and special moments to count. The Pittsburgh Steelers have won six of them, which is tied with the New England Patriots for the most in NFL history. The Patriots have a chance to pass them this weekend, however, if they‚Äôre [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
There have been 59 Super Bowls in NFL history, and thus too many great plays and special moments to count.

The Pittsburgh Steelers have won six of them, which is tied with the New England Patriots for the most in NFL history. The Patriots have a chance to pass them this weekend, however, if they‚Äôre able to upset the Seattle Seahawks.

Accordingly, it figures that either Pittsburgh or New England would have had the best play in Super Bowl history, which legendary broadcaster Al Michaels revealed this week during his appearance on the ‚ÄúFitz And Whit‚Äù podcast.

Al Michaels on James Harrison‚Äôs Super Bowl Pick six:

"You've got James Harrison what, for me, was the greatest play in Super Bowl history.‚Äù#steelers

Fitz and Whit pic.twitter.com/MIW81OEahF

‚Äî Matthew Luciow (@matthewluciow92) February 5, 2026

Michaels discussed the Steelers‚Äô exciting 27-23 victory over the Arizona Cardinals in Super Bowl XLIII, which featured a 100-yard interception return for a touchdown by Pittsburgh linebacker James Harrison off Cardinals quarterback Kurt Warner. The play set a Super Bowl record and gave the Steelers a 10-point lead heading into halftime.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve got James Harrison with, what for me, was the greatest play in Super Bowl history. A hundred-yard interception return at the end of the half. Crazy, down the sideline, he‚Äôs almost getting tackled 15 times,‚Äù recalled Michaels, who called the game for NBC.

Even though the play happened 17 years ago, Michaels still remembers it like it was yesterday. So do many Pittsburgh fans, as their team hasn‚Äôt won a Super Bowl since.

More Steelers: Steelers Reportedly Expected To Hire New Outside Linebackers Coach

title: Greenwich boys, girls capture FCIAC indoor track and field championships in New Haven
description: The boys won with 112 points, with Danbury next at 66. The girls had 116 points, with New Canaan second at 65.
fullText:
NEW HAVEN -¬†The Greenwich boys and girls indoor track and field teams were both winners at the FCIAC championships Thursday night at the Floyd Little Athletic Center.

The boys won with 112 points, with Danbury next at 66. The girls finished with 116 points, ahead of second-place New Canaan's 65.

"I think [the girls team] won all four relays, so it was really a team effort," Greenwich girls head coach Peter Watson said.

Watson also credited second- and third-place finishes that contributed to the team's success.

Cardinals boys head coach Christopher Wallace said the mentality of his athletes coming into the season has really started to pay off.

"This year is like a culmination of a lot of years of hard work for this team, and they all believe in each other and have each other's backs," Wallace said.

Greenwich's 4x200 boys relay squad of Jack Hannafin, David Boside, Daniel Silver and Alexander Yu started the meet by winning in a season-best time of 1:32.35.

Yu was also part of the 1,600 sprint medley that finished second with a season-best time of 3:45.85, and the 4x400 that finished third in 3:36.71.

"This is the best," Yu said. "Last year, I missed my FCIAC time just barely. This year, I'm back. I'm so much better and so much more prepared."

The Cardinals' 4x800 of Michael Yardis, Oliver Eaton, Benjamin Hayes and Ryan Newcomb won gold with a season-best time of 8:16.45.

On the girls side, Greenwich swept the relays thanks to standout performances from Riley Barber and Eliana Daplyn. Barber was on the 4x200 with Nina Silver, her twin sister Ella Barber and Chloe Culver, and the foursome finished with a season-best time of 1:45.15.

"I'm really proud of my teammates," Riley Barber said. "Our team is really well-rounded, and I'm just really proud of all of them. They all did really well."

Barber was also on the winning 1,600 sprint medley team, along with Daplyn, who was a member of the 4x400 with Gemma Hardwick, Chloe Culver, Margaret McCooe that took gold in a time of¬†4:09.64.

The 4x400 got interesting in the third leg when McCooe sensed that she was being passed by another runner. She looked back twice and decided to make her move, which ultimately paid off.

"The runner was right next to me, and I was going to let her pass, and then maybe try to [pass by her] then, but then I just decided to sprint the last [stretch of the race]," McCooe said.

Although the relays were where the Cardinals took command of the meet, they also had victories elsewhere.

Ryan Newcomb won the boys 600 in 1:24.79, and Jacob Mobley won the shot put with a meet record of 51 feet, and a half-inch.

Hardwick won the girls 600 in 1:38.45, and Daplyn claimed the 1,000 in 2:58.40.

Both Greenwich coaches were proud of what they saw, and are expecting more good results next Saturday in states.

"We're gonna get ready for the CIAC Class LL championship," Watson said.¬† "We've got a little bit of time to rest. We worked really hard today. We're excited to try and go in and do something special."

Boys team results: 1. Greenwich 112; 2. Danbury 66; 3. Ridgefield 42.5; 4. Brien McMahon 36; 5. Darien and Fairfield Warde 34; 7. New Canaan 31; 8. Trumbull 23; 9. Wilton 18; 10. Fairfield Ludlowe 17; 11. Staples 14.5; 12. Westhill 14; 13. Norwalk 9; 14. Bridgeport Central 8; 15. St. Joseph 6.

Girls team results: 1. Greenwich 116; 2. New Canaan 65; 3. Fairfield Ludlowe 55; 4. Ridgefield and Staples 48; 6. Brien McMahon 46; 7. Fairfield Warde 22; 8. Wilton 18; 9. Trumbull 16; 10. Darien 11; 11. Bridgeport Central and Danbury 7; 13. St. Joseph 5; 14. Norwalk 1.

This article originally published at Greenwich boys, girls capture FCIAC indoor track and field championships in New Haven.

title: Why Justin Herbert's first-place MVP vote is odd twist to Matthew Stafford victory over Drake Maye
description: Matthew Stafford beat out Drake Maye for 2026 NFL MVP by one vote, 24-23 in the closest MVP race in 22 years, however it was odd first-place nods for Justin Herbert and Josh Allen that might have made the difference.
fullText:
Why Justin Herbert's first-place MVP vote is odd twist to Matthew Stafford victory over Drake Maye originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The NFL was very close to having co-league MVP quarterbacks for the second time ever and first time in 22 years. Instead, the Rams' Matthew Stafford's margin of victory -- one first-place vote -- over the Patriots' Drake Maye (24-23) will go down as the closest decision in league history.

Not since the Colts' Peyton Manning and the late Titans great Steve McNair tied 16-16 and shared MVP in 2003 has there been such a narrow call. Stafford edging Maye was the most expected result at Thursday's Associated Press NFL Honors ceremony, but it still came with controversy considering where the three other first-place votes went.

While 47 of the 50 AP voters, which includes national beat reporters and television analysts such as Tom Brady, had a natural split between Stafford and Maye -- much like Josh Allen beating Lamar Jackson for 2024 MVP -- three went in a different direction. Two voters thought Allen should repeat and gave him a follow-up first-place love. But one inexplicably threw away their most valuable vote on Justin Herbert.

MORE:How Matthew Stafford beat out Drake Maye in closest race since 2003

There was some logic to Allen's season with the Bills being worthy of some recognition, given it was more efficient than his winning year in many ways. But Herbert's year with the Chargers shouldn't have had a real case.

Herbert wasn't even one of the five finalists "nominated" at the 2026 NFL Honors. Stafford, Maye and Allen were joined by Jaguars QB Trevor Lawrence and 49ers running back Christian McCaffrey, who both didn't get any first place votes.

Before the AP reveals on Friday how all 50 voters ranked their top five from first to fifth, the Herbert voter outed himself -- it was former Pro Football Focus analyst Sam Monson.

I was the Justin Herbert vote.

The guy had the worst offensive line in the NFL all season and despite that he was working miracles in almost every single game.

Stafford's OL became 2/5ths as bad as Herbert's for 5 minutes and he became a turnover howitzer.

He embodied 'value'.

‚Äî Sam Monson (@SamMonsonNFL) February 6, 2026

Herbert did have to deal with a broken-down offensive line with both top offensive tackles Rashawn Slater and Joe Alt going down with season-ending injuries. He was sacked 54 times and the Chargers gave up 60 as a team.

But Maye also was sacked a ton, 47 times, with his rookie left tackle Will Campbell battling inexperience and injury. Maye led the league in completion percentage (72.0), yards per pass attempt (8.9) and passer rating (113.5). He also rushed for 450 yards.

Stafford led the league with his 4,709 passing yards and 46 touchdown passes while averaging 7.9 yards per attempt and rating 109.2.

Herbert's numbers weren't close to either. He averaged 7.3 yards per attempt and rated 94.1. He threw for only 26 TDs with 13 interceptions while passing for fewer than 4,000 yards (3,727 yards). Those kind of mediocre numbers lack both efficiency and profilic nature, two things that count most in the history of the award, with MVP really being "the best quarterback in the league award".

MORE:Matthew Stafford says he‚Äôs not retiring in 2026 NFL MVP Speech

Every quarterback that wins MVP has a favorable support system. Herbert might have been let down by his team, but in the end, MVP is an award for individual performance. Had Herbert put up transcendent numbers with those challenges, it's one thing. But one cannot blame Stafford or Maye for having better all-around support systems and taking full advantage.

Herbert didn't deserve that vote, or even a fifth-place one.

title: David Ornstein Exclusive: Fee that Chelsea sold rising star for has been revealed
description: Transfer expert for The Athletic David Ornstein has revealed the fee that Liverpool have paid to sign Rio Ngumoha from Chelsea.The move at the time caused a bit of a stir because this guy is a highly ...
fullText:
Transfer expert for The Athletic David Ornstein has revealed the fee that Liverpool have paid to sign Rio Ngumoha from Chelsea.

The move at the time caused a bit of a stir because this guy is a highly rated young player, and Chelsea fans knew very well that they were losing a gem. But for whatever reason, they couldn‚Äôt keep hold of him and he made the decision to go and play for Liverpool instead and try his luck there, rather than stay at Chelsea where he came through the academy.

Some people will feel that Chelsea have got decent money for a player who was yet to even sign a professional contract, whereas others who are experts on the Blues academy will know that this fee will soon end up looking like an absolutely bargain for a player with a very high ceiling.

Rio Ngumoha celebrates scoring for Liverpool.(Photo by George Wood/Getty Images)

According to the report, Liverpool must pay an initial fee worth ¬£2.8million ‚Äî which could rise by a further ¬£4m ‚Äî for the signing of Rio Ngumoha from Chelsea. This was decided at tribunal.

I think it is safe to say that paying so little for any player in the top leagues these days will be considered a bargain. But for me, I think this fee will soon look like an absolutely bargain of the century for Liverpool ‚Äì this guy is a superb talent.

Chelsea and Strasbourg have had a ridiculous¬†12 transfers between them¬†in the last two windows. It‚Äôs all within the rules, but it‚Äôs making people uncomfortable.

Joao Pedro impressed with his performance on Tuesday night, and¬†the highlights show him¬†doing really well against a physical Gunners team.

title: Team of the Week: Parma Western looks to build off its momentum
description: LANSING, Mich. (WLNS) ‚Äî Parma Western girls basketball has won four-straight games with their most recent win coming over Holt and the Panthers believe they have begin to gel at just the right time. In the win over Holt on Tuesday, senior Rayah Hitt finished with 25 points and senior Aubree Allen finished with 23 [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
LANSING, Mich. (WLNS) ‚Äî Parma Western girls basketball has won four-straight games with their most recent win coming over Holt and the Panthers believe they have begin to gel at just the right time.

In the win over Holt on Tuesday, senior Rayah Hitt finished with 25 points and senior Aubree Allen finished with 23 points.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs great is there‚Äôs no ego‚Äôs, there‚Äôs no beef from the rest of the team,‚Äù said Parma Western basketball coach Jeff Beckman. ‚ÄúSome nights, we‚Äôve had a couple games where we‚Äôve had four in double figures so it‚Äôs just who‚Äôs hot and let‚Äôs get them the ball and it‚Äôs a great display of unselfishness.‚Äù

With that unselfishness, Beckman says his team has began to flourish and he believes one of the biggest reasons for that is the relationships his players have created and strengthened off the court.

For Hitt, who says her and her teammates push each other to their limits, she also added it‚Äôs about knowing what the team needs from each person in order to excel.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve always been a good team, a good program and I think we just needed to figure out how to work together and the cohesiveness of this team and that‚Äôs what we‚Äôre figuring out right now and we‚Äôre really starting to gel at the right time,‚Äù explained Hitt.

Hitt who one of the senior leaders of the team says each person on the team has something to give and that is what makes the Panthers successful.

‚ÄúWe know our roles on the team,‚Äù said Hitt. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a really good thing for our team cause in the past we had to learn our roles and now we‚Äôve done that and we‚Äôre really succeeding.‚Äù

Parma Western will go for its fifth straight win when they take on Portland at home on February 6th.

title: Golden Knights dominate Kings 4-1 with early scoring blitz
description: Mark Stone had a goal and two assists and the Vegas Golden Knights took control early Thursday night by scoring four times on their first six shots for a 4-1 victory over the Los Angeles Kings.  The Kings have lost four of five.  Jack Eichel and Pavel Dorofeyev each had a goal and an assist for the Golden Knights.
fullText:
LAS VEGAS (AP) ‚Äî Mark Stone had a goal and two assists and the Vegas Golden Knights took control early Thursday night by scoring four times on their first six shots for a 4-1 victory over the Los Angeles Kings.

Vegas heads into the Olympic break with back-to-back victories after losing seven of eight games. The Kings have lost four of five.

Jack Eichel and Pavel Dorofeyev each had a goal and an assist for the Golden Knights. Mitch Marner scored a goal for his 799th career point and Ivan Barbashev extended his points streak to five games with two assists.

Barbashev's four-game goal streak, however, ended. Eichel extended his points streak to four games and now has 200 assists in a Golden Knights uniform.

Vegas' Adin Hill made 32 saves for his 100th career victory, his most stops since having 34 on March 15, 2025, against Buffalo.

Trevor Moore scored for the Kings and Anton Forsberg stopped 18 shots. Adrian Kempe's eight-game points streak ended.

The Golden Knights won despite taking six penalties, though one was a fighting major shared by both teams. Los Angeles didn't make Vegas pay, going 0 of 5 on the power play. The last time the Golden Knights committed six penalties was Nov. 20 against Utah, also a 4-1 victory.

Kings forward Andrei Kuzmenko took a puck in the face with 1:42 left in the first period and was taken to the locker room. He returned, however, in the second.

Artemi Panarin, acquired by the Kings on Wednesday in a trade with the Rangers, as expected was not in the lineup. He had 57 points in 52 games for New York, but hadn't played or practiced in about a week.

Kings: Host the Golden Knights on Feb. 25.

Golden Knights: Visit the Kings on Feb. 25.

AP NHL: https://apnews.com/hub/nhl

title: Complete list of winners in 2026 NFL Honors
description: The 2026 NFL Honors celebrated the defining performances and stories of the 2025 season, recognizing excellence that went far beyond the box score. From veteran stars reaching new heights to emerging talents announcing their arrival, this year‚Äôs winners reflected the‚Ä¶
fullText:
The 2026 NFL Honors celebrated the defining performances and stories of the 2025 season, recognizing excellence that went far beyond the box score. From veteran stars reaching new heights to emerging talents announcing their arrival, this year‚Äôs winners reflected the league‚Äôs unique blend of longevity, resilience, and evolution. Together, these awards capture the moments and individuals who shaped the NFL‚Äôs narrative over the past season.

Matthew Stafford captured his first NFL MVP award after a remarkable 17th season in the league. He led the league with 4,707 passing yards and 46 touchdown passes. His performance was a career-high and pivotal in the Rams‚Äô offensive success, showcasing both precision and longevity at age 37. Stafford‚Äôs journey from years of underappreciated play in Detroit to peak form in Los Angeles adds a compelling arc to his MVP narrative. Despite his veteran status, he announced intentions to continue playing, hinting at even more chapters ahead.

Smith-Njigba emerged as the league‚Äôs top offensive weapon, setting franchise records and finishing with 1,793 receiving yards ‚Äî the most in the NFL for the 2025 season. His route running, consistency, and ability to create separation made him a matchup nightmare for defenses. He became the focal point of Seattle‚Äôs attack and proved he‚Äôs more than just a deep threat, becoming a true WR1. His production helped elevate the Seahawks into serious playoff contention.

Myles Garrett‚Äôs season will go down in history ‚Äî he shattered the NFL single-season sack record with 23 and logged 33 tackles for loss. His relentless pass rush and ability to disrupt games earned him Defensive Player of the Year honors for a second time. Garrett‚Äôs dominance, even when facing constant double teams, illustrated his evolution into one of the truly elite defenders in the league. His impact extended beyond sacks, as he altered offensive game plans weekly.

McMillan made an immediate splash in his rookie season, leading all first-year players in receiving and showcasing a polished route tree and natural ball skills. His chemistry with his quarterback and knack for big plays gave the Panthers a reliable and explosive weapon. The award signals the start of a potentially incredible NFL career, with McMillan already displaying pro-caliber instincts. His performance brought excitement to Carolina‚Äôs offense and optimism for the future.

Schwesinger arrived as a surprise standout, amassing impressive tackle totals and impact plays that anchored the Browns‚Äô defense. His instincts in coverage and physicality in run support distinguished him from his draft class peers. Winning Defensive Rookie of the Year validated his immediate contribution and hinted at future stardom. His emergence added a dynamic element to Cleveland‚Äôs defense.

Thuney‚Äôs performance as an interior offensive lineman earned him the inaugural Protector of the Year award, emphasizing his role in stabilizing the Bears‚Äô offensive front. His pass protection and run-blocking prowess helped elevate Chicago‚Äôs offensive efficiency. Known for his intelligence and technique, Thuney became a leader on the line. This award recognizes the importance of unsung linemen who anchor offensive success.

McCaffrey‚Äôs journey back from significant injury was one of the most impressive stories of the season, finishing with over 2,100 scrimmage yards and 17 touchdowns. His versatility ‚Äî as a runner, receiver, and team leader ‚Äî made him indispensable to the 49ers‚Äô offense. The award honors not just statistical excellence but resilience and dedication to rehabilitation. His triumphant return energized teammates and fans alike.

Vrabel guided the Patriots through a successful turnaround, leading them to an AFC East title and deep playoff push on his first year with the team. His leadership and game management earned recognition as Coach of the Year by his peers. Vrabel‚Äôs emphasis on culture and discipline translated into tangible improvement on the field. The award underscores his impact in transforming the Patriots into a contender.

McDaniels‚Äô role as Assistant Coach of the Year reflects his influence in shaping the Patriots‚Äô offensive identity and maximizing the talent on the roster. Known for his strategic approach and game-planning acumen, McDaniels helped elevate New England‚Äôs execution. His contributions were integral to the team‚Äôs success and competitive positioning.

Wagner was honored for his exceptional leadership on the field and impactful community service off it. The Walter Payton Man of the Year Award recognizes players who demonstrate commitment to their communities, and Wagner‚Äôs efforts have extended well beyond football. His charitable initiatives and mentorship work set a standard for NFL players. The award celebrates character and civic contribution.

Taken as a whole, the complete list of 2026 NFL Honors winners tells the story of a season driven by elite play, leadership, and perseverance. Each awardee left a distinct imprint on their team and, in many cases, the broader direction of the league. As the NFL turns the page to a new season, these honorees stand as benchmarks for excellence and reminders of how special the 2025 campaign truly was.

The post Complete list of winners in 2026 NFL Honors appeared first on The Big Lead.

title: Lasses Preview: Friday Nights Under The Lights!
description: Charlotte Patterson previews tonight‚Äôs clash between Sunderland Women and Sheffield United ‚Äî a big game awaits!
fullText:
A February night under the lights at Eppleton always carries its own kind of electricity, but tonight‚Äôs game feels particularly charged.

Sunderland Women welcome Sheffield United in a fixture that arrives at a pivotal moment for both clubs, with each navigating the fine margins of a league table where a handful of points separate mid‚Äëtable security from the creeping anxiety of a relegation battle.

It‚Äôs the sort of match that can tilt a season‚Äôs momentum for better or worse, and the sort of occasion that demands clarity, resilience and a rediscovery of identity. For Sunderland in particular, it feels like a moment to steady the ship, to respond and to remind themselves ‚Äî and everyone watching ‚Äî of the football they‚Äôre capable of producing.

The Lasses‚Äô recent run of form has been a frustrating blend of promise and inconsistency, with their loss to Bristol City standing out as a particularly bruising setback. Heading into that match, there was a sense that Sunderland were beginning to stitch together some cohesion, even if results hadn‚Äôt always reflected the performances.

Sadly, the trip to Bristol unravelled in a way that will have disappointed Mel Reay and her squad.

Bristol were sharper in key moments and more decisive in both boxes, and Sunderland struggled to impose themselves in the way they had earlier in the season.

The defeat wasn‚Äôt simply about the scoreline ‚Äî it was the manner of it as Sunderland looked disjointed, unable to find the rhythm that had defined their best spells of the campaign, and too often second to loose balls and transitional moments.

The most concerning aspect was the lack of attacking fluency.

Earlier in the season, Sunderland carved teams open with quick combinations, intelligent movement and a willingness to commit bodies forward. Against Bristol, that spark was missing.

Passes that would normally split lines instead drifted into congested areas, wide players found themselves isolated and the midfield ‚Äî usually a source of control and tempo ‚Äî struggled to dictate. Bristol capitalised, pressing aggressively and forcing Sunderland into rushed decisions.

It was the sort of performance that leaves a team not just disappointed but reflective, and with tough fixtures looming Sunderland know they can‚Äôt afford to let that result remain in their system.

If Sunderland‚Äôs form has been uneven, Sheffield United‚Äôs have been quietly gathering momentum, culminating in a very impressive 1‚Äì1 draw against Charlton Athletic ‚Äî a result that, in context, brought far more than just a point. Charlton have been one of the strongest sides in the division ‚Äî both in terms of form and league position, ‚Äî and Sheffield‚Äôs ability to go toe‚Äëto‚Äëtoe with them was a statement of intent.

I watched that match myself and it was impossible not to be struck by the level of intensity and organisation Sheffield brought to the pitch.

They pressed Charlton relentlessly, especially in the first half, swarming with four or five players at a time whenever Charlton attempted to build from goal kicks. It wasn‚Äôt reckless pressing ‚Äî it was coordinated, intelligent and suffocating.

What impressed me most was how consistently Sheffield sustained that pressure.

Charlton aren‚Äôt easily rattled yet Sheffield forced them into hurried clearances, misplaced passes and uncomfortable defensive sequences. The energy levels were remarkable, and the tactical discipline even more so.

As a neutral observer, it was exhilarating to watch; as a Sunderland supporter, it was slightly worrying as Sheffield looked like a side with belief, clarity and a willingness to work for every inch of the pitch, and one player who stood out was former Sunderland midfielder Mollie Rouse.

Her performance was a reminder of the qualities she brought during her time on Wearside: composure, vision and an ability to knit play together with subtle but incisive touches.

Against Charlton, she was central to Sheffield‚Äôs best moments. Her through balls repeatedly carved open space and her link‚Äëup play helped Sheffield transition from pressing to possession with fluidity. She seemed to anticipate the movement of teammates before the ball even reached her feet, and her presence gave Sheffield a creative axis that Charlton struggled to contain.

The match itself was intense from start to finish, with both sides trading periods of control and half‚Äëchances, but the closing stages belonged to Sheffield.

They created two huge opportunities in the dying minutes ‚Äî chances that, on another day, would‚Äôve secured all three points. The fact that they were still pushing with such conviction so late in the game spoke volumes about their fitness, mentality, and ambition, and it was a performance that‚Äôll have boosted their confidence significantly heading into tonight‚Äôs clash.

The head‚Äëto‚Äëhead history between Sunderland and Sheffield United adds another layer of intrigue to this fixture.

Sheffield got the better of the Lasses in the League Cup earlier this season, in a result that stung not just because of the defeat itself, but because Sunderland struggled to impose their style on the match, and it was a reminder that Sheffield are more than capable of disrupting Sunderland‚Äôs rhythm and exploiting lapses in concentration.

However, the league meeting between the sides at the start of the 2025/2026 season told a very different story as Sunderland travelled to Bramall Lane and produced one of their most complete performances in recent memory, dismantling Sheffield 0-4 with a display of free‚Äëflowing, incisive attacking football.

Everything clicked that day: the movement, the passing patterns, the pressing triggers, the confidence in possession.

It was the sort of performance that set expectations for the season ahead and showcased the attacking identity Sunderland have been striving to recapture. Unfortunately, that brand of football has been harder to find in recent weeks. The contrast between that opening‚Äëday brilliance and the more laboured performances of late is stark, and Friday night offers an opportunity, perhaps even a necessity, to rediscover that spark.

This match carries weight not just because of form or history, but because of the broader context of the league table.

Both Sunderland and Sheffield United find themselves amid a cluster of teams separated by only a few points, where a single win can propel a side toward mid‚Äëtable comfort and a single defeat can drag them back into relegation battle. It‚Äôs a precarious position ‚Äî one that demands consistency and resilience, and where every point matters, every mistake is magnified and every moment of quality becomes decisive.

For Sunderland, the urgency is heightened by the fixtures that lie ahead.

Tough tests are on the horizon and dropping points at home ‚Äî especially in a match against a direct competitor, ‚Äî would place additional pressure on those upcoming challenges.

The crowd will be expectant, vocal and eager to see a response to the disappointment at Bristol. There‚Äôa something about these evening fixtures that often brings out the best in Sunderland teams, and the players will know that this is a moment to rise to the occasion.

The key for Sunderland will be re‚Äëestablishing control in midfield and rediscovering the attacking patterns that defined their early‚Äëseason success.

They need to move the ball with purpose, stretch Sheffield‚Äôs defensive shape and avoid being drawn into the chaotic, high‚Äëpressing game that Sheffield executed so effectively against Charlton. If Sunderland can dictate the tempo, they can create the sort of chances that‚Äôve been lacking in recent matches, but if they allow Sheffield to set the rhythm, press aggressively and force turnovers, the match could become uncomfortable very quickly.

Defensively, Sunderland will need to be alert to Sheffield‚Äôs transitions.

The Blades showed against Charlton that they can break with pace and precision ‚Äî especially when Rouse is given space in which to operate. Sunderland‚Äôs defence will need to communicate clearly, track runners diligently and avoid the lapses that proved costly against Bristol. Concentration will be crucial, particularly in the opening stages when Sheffield are likely to press with intensity.

Psychologically, this match is an opportunity for Sunderland to reset.

A win would not only provide valuable points but also restore confidence and momentum. It would demonstrate that the Bristol result was a blip rather than a trend, and that the team remains capable of producing the football that defined their best performances earlier in the campaign.

For Sheffield, it represents a chance to build on their impressive draw with Charlton and to continue to climb away from the lower reaches of the table ‚Äî and they‚Äôll arrive with belief, energy, and a clear game plan.

What makes this fixture so compelling is that both sides have shown glimpses of their potential but have also struggled for consistency.

Both have strengths that can trouble the opposition, both sides have vulnerabilities that can be exploited and both teams understand the stakes. It‚Äôs the sort of match where the first goal could be decisive, where momentum could swing dramatically and where individual moments of quality may determine the outcome.

As a Sunderland supporter, there‚Äôs a natural desire to see the team respond with conviction, to see the patterns of play that lit up the early weeks of the season and to see the players embrace the occasion. But having watched Sheffield‚Äôs performance against Charlton, there‚Äôs also an awareness that this will be far from straightforward.

Sheffield are organised, hungry, and capable of unsettling even the strongest sides. They won‚Äôt come to sit back; instead, they‚Äôll come to compete, to press and to test Sunderland‚Äôs composure.

Ultimately, tonight feels like a crossroads.

Sunderland can either use this match to reassert themselves, to reclaim their identity and to put daylight between themselves and the teams below ‚Äî or they can allow the uncertainty of recent weeks to linger.

The choice is theirs, and the stage is set.

title: USA Olympic figure skating results: Updated scores, winners for 2026 team, singles and pairs events

title: Simon Adingra‚Äôs Exit Is A Sign Of The Times At Sunderland
description: "Loaning out such a high-profile player sends a very strong message in itself‚Äù, writes Phil West of Adingra‚Äôs departure
fullText:
When Granit Xhaka took what felt like ten Leeds United players out of the game with a sumptuous pass to Simon Adingra, who then composed himself before curling a smart finish beyond the dive of Lucas Perri at the Stadium of Light back in December, was I the only Sunderland fan whose first thought was ‚ÄúNow he‚Äôs truly arrived and we‚Äôll see what he can bring to the table if he‚Äôs given an extended run in the side‚Äù?

As we eventually shared the spoils with the visitors from Elland Road, that goal really felt like a breakthrough moment for the Ivory Coast international.

To my mind, it was the perfect response to being omitted from his country‚Äôs AFCON squad and as he dropped to his knees in celebration with his teammates surrounding him, I really believed we‚Äôd seen something that would kickstart his Sunderland career, putting him back into favour with R√©gis Le Bris after murmurings about his work rate and defensive diligence.

Sadly, things didn‚Äôt work out that way.

Just over one month later, Adingra has made a swift Wearside exit after being loaned to Ligue 1 side AS Monaco, with Ecuadorian winger Nilson Angulo set to arrive from Anderlecht as the latest addition to our talented legion of wingmen.

A sharp, ruthless and possibly brutal reversal of fortune? Perhaps. A move that in some ways is justifiable and was needed for both the benefit of the squad and Adingra himself? Many would say yes.

In the first instance, his summer signing from Brighton was by no means the most ill-advised we could‚Äôve made as we sought pace and dynamism on the flanks ahead of our return to the Premier League.

As a 2023 AFCON champion and a player who was seemingly highly rated down on the south coast ‚Äî albeit with a cautionary note sounded about his consistency when the opinions of Brighton fans were canvassed before and after his transfer was completed ‚Äî I was excited by his arrival on Wearside and was hopeful that he could make a major impact in the red and white stripes.

Sadly, despite his goal against Leeds and an assist during our opening-day victory over West Ham, his spell at the Stadium of Light hasn‚Äôt lived up to that initial promise and it feels unlikely that he‚Äôll play any further part in what we all hope will be Sunderland‚Äôs story of continued progress during 2026 and beyond.

Although we‚Äôve at least cushioned any financial blow by virtue of how we‚Äôve structured his loan arrangement, it does represent a rare blip in terms of representing a transfer that didn‚Äôt work out as planned ‚Äî albeit with our strike rate for new signings still more than good enough to deem that particular window a success.

The speed at which Adingra was moved on surprised me.

As recently as last weekend, I felt he would be given further opportunities to play his way back into form and prove that he could make the grade at this level, but it also brought into sharp focus the standards being set, the demands placed on our players and the qualities you‚Äôre expected to bring to the table.

Nowadays, Sunderland is a club where careers can be launched and reputations enhanced, but no new signing will find the going easy and in the quest to establish ourselves as a genuine competitive force at this level, that‚Äôs the way it has to be ‚Äî and occasionally in spite of supporters such as myself who are eager to see players given every opportunity to prove their worth even as their form fluctuates.

It‚Äôs obvious that despite his Gallic charm, level-headed interviews and even-tempered nature, Le Bris is a hard taskmaster.

In order to earn and retain a place in a team coached by him, you must combine skill, footballing intelligence, physicality, adaptability and perhaps most importantly a willingness to graft for the entirety of the ninety minutes.

Adingra‚Äôs profile and style of play ‚Äî that of a winger who plays off the front foot, was more effective in wide open spaces and for whom tracking back perhaps wasn‚Äôt a high priority ‚Äî has evidently not gelled with the head coach‚Äôs ideals and therefore a parting of the ways feels mutually beneficial.

With any luck, Angulo will prove to be another previously unearthed gem of an addition and we can continue to work on the attacking side of our game during the remaining games of the season, but loaning out such a high-profile player sends a very strong message in itself: talent alone isn‚Äôt enough nowadays, and no decision will be shirked if the team can possibly benefit as a result.

That in itself feels like a bit of a shock given our historical reputation for indulging players who didn‚Äôt perform consistently enough, but hopefully Adingra can use this opportunity as a chance to reset and get back into the groove ‚Äî and the club deserves credit for ensuring that a very talented footballer will be playing at a decent level for the remainder of the campaign.

title: Barcelona Femen√≠ march into Copa de la Reina semi-finals with statement win over Real Madrid
description: Alexia, Pajor, and Salma shine as the Blaugrana dominate in the capital
fullText:
FC Barcelona‚Äôs women put on a show at the Alfredo Di St√©fano, leaving Real Madrid behind in a 4-0 quarter-final. The win books their place in the Copa de la Reina semifinals.

Alexia Putellas opened the scoring with a towering header from a Caroline Graham Hansen corner, Ewa Pajor scored a brace, and Salma Paralluelo added another goal, with Patri Guijarro pulling the strings in midfield.

The night started rough. Heavy rain, strong wind, and a boggy pitch made passing tricky, and Madrid came out with intensity, pressing high and trying to force errors. Early interventions from Irene Paredes and Vicky L√≥pez kept Barcelona afloat, but the real drama came in the 15th minute. Laia Aleixandri collided with Feller and went down clutching her knee. She had to leave on a stretcher, visibly shaken. A√Øcha Camara had to come on, but the team kept rolling.

The opener arrived in the 20th minute. Alexia rose unmarked and sent a header past Misa. She celebrated with her hand to her ear, and suddenly, the game became livelier.

Vicky L√≥pez hit the post, Cl√†udia Pina‚Äôs shots were blocked, and for Madrid, an Athenea del Castillo goal was correctly ruled out for offside. By halftime, Barcelona led 1-0, in a calm but commanding fashion.

After the break, the Catalans shifted up a gear. Pajor struck a powerful shot to double the lead, then Salma finished off a perfect through ball from Patri to make it 3-0. Salma sprinted down the left and laid the ball off for Pajor, who controlled with her chest and slotted it coolly to score the fourth and final goal. By the final whistle, Barcelona had accomplished their mission and were onto the next round.

The other three teams left to compete for the cup are Atl√©tico de Madrid, Tenerife, and Badalona Women.
